sub_topic: Finding the determinant of a matrix
message_2:
To find the determinant of a 3x3 matrix, we can use the following formula:

det(A) = a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)

where a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i are the elements of the matrix:

\begin{equation}
\begin{vmatrix} 
a & b & c \\ 
d & e & f \\ 
g & h & i 
\end{vmatrix}
\end{equation}

In this case, the matrix is:

\begin{equation}
\begin{vmatrix} 
2 & 3 & 1 \\ 
1 & -2 & 4 \\ 
3 & 4 & -3 
\end{vmatrix}
\end{equation}

So, we have:

a = 2, b = 3, c = 1
d = 1, e = -2, f = 4
g = 3, h = 4, i = -3

Now, we can calculate the determinant:

det(A) = 2((-2)(-3) - (4)(4)) - 3((1)(-3) - (4)(3)) + 1((1)(4) - (-2)(3))

det(A) = 2(6 - 16) - 3(-3 - 12) + (4 + 6)

det(A) = 2(-10) + 3(15) + 10

det(A) = -20 + 45 + 10

det(A) = 35

So, the determinant of the given matrix is 35.
